overall_summary: The reasoning demonstrates a practical approach to time-series forecasting focused on handling limited data (96 points) and anomalies. It prioritizes simplicity by leveraging observable daily patterns while explicitly addressing data anomalies (e.g., a constant-value day). The method emphasizes data completeness and timestamp generation, with calculations tailored to the dataset's hourly frequency and value ranges.
common_data_patterns: Anomaly detection (constant-value day treated as outlier)
Negative values during day, positive at night
key_insights: Exclusion of anomalous data (constant-value day) from pattern calculations
Preference for recent data (last two normal days) over full history for pattern extraction
Explicit handling of timestamp generation for multi-day forecasts
Rounding conventions matching input data precision
Acknowledgment of limitations in modeling trends or weekly seasonality due to short data
complexity_analysis: Moderately complex with strong practical adaptations: Combines data quality checks, anomaly handling, and pattern-based heuristics. Avoids advanced statistical models (e.g., SARIMA) due to data constraints, opting for interpretable averaging techniques instead.
